subject: Re: [junit] Using System.out.println("something") ???
msgSnippet: ... The primary goal of JUnit is to automate the tests.  This means that you shouldn t need a manual inspection of the tests results.  Having println()s is
messageBody:
> What do you say about using printing to console in a JUnit test?

The primary goal of JUnit is to automate the tests. This means that you
shouldn't need a "manual" inspection of the tests' results. Having println()s
is just the opposite of what you should have.

- replace the println by an assertEquals and leave the assertion there once it
has been written.

- you would like to have a println in your production code, use a logger (log4J,
commons-logging) instead

- if the JUnit assert you're using is not specific enough (and you end up
writing printlns to know where the real error is) use or develop a custom
assertion (the well-known package features several custom assertions)

-Vladimir

--
Vladimir R. Bossicard
